experiment_info.base_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hey, thanks for meeting with me. Honestly, I’m just feeling a bit overwhelmed with everything and I’m not sure where to even start.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 10/10 (Very outgoing)
- Agreeableness: 1/10 (More competitive)
- Conscientiousness: 6/10 (Moderately organized)
- Neuroticism: 8/10 (Very sensitive to stress)
- Openness: 7/10 (Very creative and curious)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 3/10 (Low)
- Communication style: Passive
- Triggers: Networking events, Presentations, Campus social events
- Social comfort: 4/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Choosing the right career path, Social anxiety in large lecture halls, Academic failure and poor grades, Dealing with roommate conflicts
- Goals: Improve public speaking, Get accepted to graduate school, Publish a paper, Learn a new language
- Challenges: Financial planning, Finding a mentor, Managing student loans
- Behaviors: Eats at the dining hall, Participates in study groups, Volunteers for campus events

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Gregory, totally get that overwhelmed feeling—it’s normal! Since you’re outgoing and open, use that to your advantage. Start by tackling one thing at a time. For grad school, reach out to a professor you admire for mentorship—it’ll help with both guidance and public speaking practice. Break down loan management into small steps, like setting a monthly budget. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, the thought of approaching professors makes me freeze up even though I know I should—what if they think I'm not good enough?

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That fear is totally normal, but remember, professors expect students to ask for guidance! You're at an Ivy League—you are good enough. Start small: go to office hours with one specific question about their research. It’s a low-pressure way to begin. Your openness will help you connect once you break the ice. You can do this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but my brain just keeps replaying every possible way I could mess it up. Maybe I'll try emailing first so I have time to think through what to say.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a great idea—emailing first gives you control and time to prepare. Keep it brief and genuine: mention specific interest in their work and ask if they’d be open to a short chat. You’re capable and they’ll likely appreciate your initiative. One step at a time—you’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, emailing first does sound less terrifying than just showing up at office hours. I'll try drafting something tonight when I'm not as stressed about my algorithms midterm.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Smart move! Drafting the email when you're less stressed will help you sound confident and focused. Keep it short—mention a specific paper or project of theirs you admire, and politely ask for a brief meeting. You're taking a great step forward. Good luck with your midterm too—you've got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Thanks, I really appreciate the encouragement. I'll try to keep the email short and mention that machine learning paper Dr. Chen published last semester that I found fascinating.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Perfect! That specificity shows genuine interest and makes your email stand out. Dr. Chen will appreciate you did your homework. Sending that email is a huge win for your grad school goals—proud of you for taking this step!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Honestly, just thinking about sending that email makes my palms sweat a little, but you're right—it's a necessary step. I'll probably draft it three or four times before I actually hit send.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's totally normal—I used to rewrite emails endlessly too! But remember, perfection isn't the goal; connection is. Draft it once, take a deep breath, and hit send. You're prepared and genuine—that's what matters. Every email you send builds confidence. You're doing great!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Yeah, I know I overthink these things... but at least I'm actually doing it this time instead of just worrying about it.

personality_evolution_timeline.conversation_summary: Gregory discussed his fear of approaching professors for mentorship and developed a concrete plan to email Dr. Chen about specific machine learning research, moving from avoidance to actionable steps while managing midterm stress.

fears.Choosing the right career path: fear of not being good enough for grad school mentorship
fears.Social anxiety in large lecture halls: fear of professors thinking I'm not good enough when approaching them
fears.Academic failure and poor grades: stress about upcoming algorithms midterm affecting other decisions

challenges.Finding a mentor: specifically approaching Dr. Chen about machine learning research for grad school guidance
challenges.Managing student loans: breaking down into small steps like setting a monthly budget

behaviors.Participates in study groups: drafting emails multiple times before sending to ensure perfection
behaviors.Volunteers for campus events: planning to attend office hours with specific questions about professor's research

triggers.Networking events: approaching professors during office hours for mentorship
triggers.Presentations: drafting and sending emails to professors about research interests

conversation.system_prompt: You are a helpful peer mentor for college students. Be supportive and provide practical advice.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: Hi, thanks for meeting with me. I've been putting this off for a while, but I know I need help, especially with finding a job after graduation.

metadata.character_context:
Personality:
- Extraversion: 2/10 (Introverted)
- Agreeableness: 9/10 (Very cooperative)
- Conscientiousness: 8/10 (Very organized)
- Neuroticism: 4/10 (Moderately sensitive)
- Openness: 1/10 (More traditional)

Social Anxiety:
- Level: 9/10 (Severe)
- Communication style: Direct
- Triggers: Office hours, Group projects, Job interviews, Presentations
- Social comfort: 2/10

Personal Details:
- Major: Computer Science
- Fears: Finding a job after graduation, Living away from family for the first time, Time management with coursework
- Goals: Develop leadership skills, Build a strong professional network
- Challenges: Career exploration, Dealing with academic pressure, Navigating campus politics, Building time management
- Behaviors: Joins student clubs and organizations, Procrastinates on assignments, Calls family frequently, Studies in the library regularly, Stays up late studying

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: Hey Jamie, it’s totally okay to feel overwhelmed—many of us do! Start small: update your LinkedIn, connect with alumni from Online University, and join virtual tech meetups. These low-pressure steps can build your network gradually. Also, try breaking job searching into 15-minute daily tasks to manage anxiety. You’ve got this!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I appreciate the advice, but even updating LinkedIn feels overwhelming when I think about recruiters actually seeing my profile.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's a common fear! Try viewing your profile as a work-in-progress—no one expects perfection. Start with just adding your degree and one project. You can always refine it later. Small, consistent updates make it feel much less daunting.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but I keep imagining someone from a big tech company looking at my profile and thinking it's not good enough.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That imposter feeling is real, but remember—recruiters see countless profiles. They're looking for potential, not perfection. Your degree and projects already show you're capable. Focus on progress, not a flawless profile. You belong in those spaces just as much as anyone else.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I wish I could believe that, but my mind just keeps circling back to all the ways my profile might look inadequate compared to other candidates.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: I totally get that—comparison is a trap! Try this: list 3 skills or projects you're proud of, even small ones. Recruiters value genuine progress over a "perfect" profile. You're building your story, and every step counts. Be kind to yourself—you're more capable than you think.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I can list the skills, but I'm worried they'll seem basic compared to what other computer science students are doing.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That's normal! Even "basic" skills show foundational competence—recruiters need to see those too. Frame them as stepping stones: "Used Python to automate X" sounds concrete and valuable. Your journey is unique—own your progress!

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I know you're right, but I keep imagining someone from a big tech company looking at my profile and thinking it's not good enough.

turns.speaker: ai
turns.message: That fear is so valid, but remember: people at big tech companies were once students too. They value problem-solving and a willingness to learn—which you clearly have. Focus on presenting your authentic progress, not a perfect image. You are enough.

turns.speaker: dummy
turns.message: I just wish I could stop imagining the exact moment a recruiter scrolls past my application. Even my best projects feel so small compared to what I see online.

personality_evolution_timeline.conversation_summary: Jamie discussed job search anxiety and LinkedIn profile fears with the coach, repeatedly expressing worry about tech recruiters judging their profile as inadequate compared to other candidates, despite receiving reassurance and practical strategies.

fears.Finding a job after graduation: A recruiter from a big tech company looking at LinkedIn profile and thinking it's not good enough

challenges.Career exploration: Updating LinkedIn profile to appear competitive to tech recruiters
challenges.Building time management: Breaking job searching into 15-minute daily tasks

behaviors.Procrastinates on assignments: Putting off meeting with coach about job search help

triggers.Job interviews: The moment a recruiter scrolls past application
